subsections.title: Part B: Reading Comprehension
subsections.passage:
The octopus is one of the most fascinating creatures in the ocean. With eight long arms covered in suction cups, this intelligent animal can perform incredible feats. Octopuses are masters of camouflage, able to change both the color and texture of their skin to match their surroundings in less than a second. This ability helps them hide from predators and sneak up on prey.

Despite having no bones, octopuses are remarkably strong and flexible. They can squeeze through openings as small as their beaks, which are the only hard parts of their bodies. Scientists have discovered that octopuses are highly intelligent, capable of solving complex puzzles and even using tools. In laboratory studies, octopuses have opened jars to reach food inside and have learned to navigate mazes.

Perhaps most surprisingly, octopuses have three hearts and blue blood! Two hearts pump blood to the gills, while the third pumps blood to the rest of the body. Their blood is blue because it contains copper-based molecules called hemocyanin, which are better at transporting oxygen in cold, low-oxygen environments than the iron-based hemoglobin found in human blood.

choices: B) Octopuses have many remarkable characteristics.
C) Octopuses live in cold water.
D) Octopuses are difficult to study.

choices: A) Only to hide from predators
B) To communicate with other octopuses
C) To hide from predators and sneak up on prey

choices: B) Able to bend and squeeze easily

choices: B) They can change color quickly.
C) They can solve puzzles and use tools.
D) They have eight arms with suction cups.

choices: A) It makes them swim faster.
B) It helps them change color.
C) It contains copper-based molecules that transport oxygen better in their environment.

B) Entertain readers with funny octopus stories
C) Inform readers about interesting octopus characteristics
D) Teach readers how to catch octopuses

choices: A) They enjoy being studied by scientists.
B) They can learn and remember information.
C) They prefer to live in labs rather than oceans.
D) They are afraid of humans.

subsections.title: Passage 2: The History of Flight
subsections.passage:
For centuries, humans dreamed of soaring through the sky like birds. While ancient civilizations created myths about winged humans and gods who could fly, it wasn't until the late 18th century that humans achieved real flight. In 1783, the Montgolfier brothers launched the first successful hot air balloon in France, carrying passengers high above the ground. This was a thrilling breakthrough, but the balloon could only drift with the wind—it couldn't be steered.

The next major advancement came in 1903 when Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first powered, controlled airplane flight in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. Their aircraft, the Wright Flyer, stayed airborne for only 12 seconds and traveled just 120 feet, but this brief flight changed the world forever. The Wright brothers had solved the puzzle of controlled flight by carefully studying how birds use their wings to balance and steer.

Aviation technology advanced rapidly after the Wright brothers' success. During World War I, airplanes were used for reconnaissance and combat. In 1927, Charles Lindbergh became the first person to fly solo nonstop across the Atlantic Ocean, a journey that took 33 hours. By the 1950s, commercial jet airliners like the Boeing 707 made air travel faster and more accessible to ordinary people. Today, millions of passengers fly every day, and modern aircraft can travel at speeds exceeding 500 miles per hour, making the world more connected than ever before.

choices: B) It couldn't be steered or controlled.
C) It was too expensive to build.
D) It couldn't fly very high.

choices: A) They copied designs from other inventors.
B) They studied how birds use their wings.
C) They used more powerful engines.
D) They made their plane lighter.

choices: A) Charles Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic.
B) The Wright brothers flew the Wright Flyer.
C) The Montgolfier brothers launched a hot air balloon.

questions.question_text: Why does the author mention that the Wright Flyer only flew for 12 seconds?
choices: A) To show that the flight was a failure
B) To emphasize how far aviation has come since then
C) To criticize the Wright brothers
D) To explain why people didn't believe in airplanes

choices: A) It has changed very little over the past century.
B) It advanced rapidly after the Wright brothers' first flight.
C) It was only developed for military purposes.
D) It has made travel slower but safer.

sections.passage:
In the heart of a bustling city, tucked between two tall apartment buildings, there once existed a forgotten garden. No one knew who planted it or why it was there, but tall sunflowers, clusters of lavender, and vines of cherry tomatoes thrived in its cozy corner, shielded from the noise and rush. The residents passed it by daily, barely giving it a second glance—until one day, everything changed.

A girl named Maya, curious and observant, noticed the garden one afternoon as she returned home from school. A shimmering butterfly had caught her eye, leading her through a narrow alley and into the tiny green oasis. It was as though she had stepped into a different world. A wooden bench stood under an ivy-covered arch, birds chirped from the fence, and in the center grew an ancient plum tree whose trunk twisted like the strokes of a paintbrush.

Maya visited daily. She brought a notebook, sketching flowers, noting the wildlife, and documenting the growth of vegetables. Soon, others followed. An elderly man brought his harmonica, playing soft tunes that mingled with the breeze. A teacher from the local school began a composting project with her students. A once-forgotten space became a place of connection and creativity.

But as the garden flourished, developers took notice. One morning, a sign appeared: "Future Site of Luxury Apartments." The neighborhood buzzed with concern. Maya, heartbroken but determined, launched a campaign to save the garden. She held petitions, wrote articles, and even organized a "Garden Day" where neighbors shared their stories and planted new seeds.

The community's efforts reached the city council. After much deliberation and several town hall meetings, the land was designated a protected community space. The sign was removed, and in its place, a plaque was installed: "The People's Garden – A Sanctuary for Growth, Nature, and Unity."

Years later, Maya, now a botanist, often visited the garden that first sparked her love for nature. And every time she sat on the wooden bench beneath the plum tree, she remembered the butterfly—and the moment everything changed.

B. She was searching for vegetables.
C. She heard music coming from inside.
D. She wanted to hide from a storm.

C. She organized efforts to save the garden.

What is the main theme of the passage?

B. The benefits of real estate development
C. The power of community and nature
D. The history of gardening in cities

sections.passage:
It began with a whisper.

At first, no one noticed the new girl, Samira, sitting quietly in the back of Mr. Langston's 10th-grade English class. Her presence barely rippled the room's typical morning chaos: the scraping of metal chairs, the thud of backpacks, the murmur of gossip floating like smoke. She was a shadow—visible but unacknowledged.

(Passage continues with story about Samira and her journey of finding her voice...)

sections.instructions: Read the passage carefully. Then answer the questions that follow, which assess your ability to interpret, analyze, and evaluate the structure, purpose, and meaning of the text. Use textual evidence where necessary.
sections.passage: In the early spring of 1925, nestled deep within the Tennessee Valley, the town of Dayton stood on the precipice of an unexpected spotlight...John T. Scopes, a substitute teacher and football coach, had little reason to defy the state...Reporters from New York, Chicago, and beyond flooded the town...The trial was more than a legal proceeding; it was a stage for national identity...Outside the courthouse, Dayton buzzed with activity...As the civil rights era advanced, the judicial system found itself pressed between the will of the people and the promises of the Constitution...Thurgood Marshall, the nation's first African American Supreme Court Justice, once said...The impact of Brown went beyond its immediate implications...In the decades following Brown, the courts would hear cases on gender equality, voting rights, and disability access...

sections.instructions: Choose two (2) of the four prompts below. Write your responses in full paragraphs. questions.question_text: "The cost of progress is often paid by those who never benefit from it." Write an argumentative response agreeing or disagreeing with this statement. Use examples from literature, history, or current events to support your reasoning.

A student argues: 'Social media has become the modern-day diary, but it lacks privacy and reflection.' Do you agree or disagree? Write a personal or persuasive response that explores how social media influences personal growth, communication, or self-awareness.

Read this quote from author James Baldwin: "Not everything that is faced can be changed. But nothing can be changed until it is faced." Write an analytical essay that explains what Baldwin means and how this idea can be applied to one or more societal challenges today.
